material.mattext: Recall that the mean number of defective products in an hour for Xaviers production line (the mean of X) was 1.8. Based on your observation, which of the following do you think is true about the mean of Y?
The mean of Y is greater than 1.8
The mean of Y is less than 1.8
The mean of Y is roughly equal to 1.8
Look at both distributions. Where is most of the "weight" (probability), on the smaller values or on larger values?

Good Job! Indeed, the probability distribution of Y has most of the weight (80%) on the larger values (3,4), while the distribution of X has most of the "weight" (70%) on the smaller values (0,1,2). Since the mean is a weighted average of the values weighted by their probabilities, we would expect the mean of Y to be larger than the mean of X which is 1.8

Incorrect. Note that the probability distribution of Y has most of the weight (80%) on the larger values (3,4), while the distribution of X has most of the "weight" (70%) on the smaller values (0,1,2). Recall the the mean of a random variable is a weighted average of it's values weighted by the corresponding probabilities, and try again.
